G.name: Agate (Chalcedony) - Kaolinite
G.description: 11.8 x 10.5 x 7.8 cm. A surreal, otherworldly and rare large old pseudomorph from this well-known agate geode producing Rio Grande do Sul district. Kaolinite has replaced most of a striking two-sided agate geode with stunning, dense, sculptural banding. You can see a bit of remnant agate on one side of the piece. The upper and lower outer rinds on this fantastic, rare geode pseudomorph adds even more visual appeal. The Salto do Jacui area is well-known as a major source of agate in the form of geodes from Brazil (MINDAT). Unique old-time material from a limited mid-1960s find.

G.name: Agate (Chalcedony) - Quartz
G.description: One of the best non-typical Oco agates I have seen in any size.

G.name: Amethyst (Quartz) - Agate (Chalcedony)
G.description: 7.5 x 7.4 x 4.2 cm and 7.7 x 7.6 x 3.2 cm. A classic quartz-lined geodes from Las Choyas, Mexico featuring crystallized purple amethyst with beautifully banded blue agate around the periphery. Both halves are polished showing colors ranging from a soft silvery-blue to nearly white around the exterior edges with rich purple in the center. This set comes from the collection of Willard W. Wulff (1904-1998) of Colorado Springs, Colorado, a prominent figure and collector of Colorado minerals. Wulff was one of the founding members of the Colorado Springs Mineralogical Society in 1936.

G.name: Azurite
G.description: This nodule was recovered from Kaolin on a bench 10 meters above the water table. This style of nodule is deceptive as most are in fact Azurite Geodes with splendent crystals growing on the inside. Those recovered from zones near the water table tended to be solid, and most had cores of copper or chalcocite. Often these had Malachite growing on the surface of the nodule.

G.name: Calcite - Dolomite
G.description: This is a large cabinet specimen of calcite and dolomite in a geode from Indiana Route 56, Washington County, Indiana, United States. This specimen was collected by Bob Harman in 2015 and was on display at the 2019 Cincinnati, Ohio Mineral Show.
G.luster: Vitreous to pearly on cleavage surfaces

G.name: Celestine
G.description: Classic, gem gray-blue celestine crystals fill a geode on this large specimen from the classic locale at Sakoany. The freestanding crystal with the classic chisel termination is about 5.5 cm long and the large crystal attached to the walls is about 7.0 cm long. Sakoany celestines are the world's finest and this is a large richly filled geode. Weighs 2420 grams or 5.3 pounds. Ex Paul Zerfass Collection.

G.name: Kutnohorite - Aragonite
G.description: Self collected in 2005, very nice and almost perfectly round geode.

G.name: Quartz
G.description: These new and interesting pink quartz specimens from the Choique Mine made a big splash in 2019. We've seen them all over the place with various marketing names such as 'Rose' or 'Strawberry' oddly 'Pink Amethyst'. I have to point out that in my mind the term amethyst is indicative of the color purple, so I wouldn't necessarily use it to describe these specimens. This follows the same thoughts that I have to discourage the use of the term 'green amethyst' for prasem quartz. With that said it's not easy to determine an accurate term to describe this material because it's genuinely unique and doesn't quite look like any quartz specimens from any other locality. It's not quite the same color as rose quartz that we're used to seeing from places like Brazil, as it has a slightly orange overtone, so 'pink' might be the best term for them for the time being. These pieces are found as loose geodes and cracked open to expose the beautiful crystals within. This particular piece is lined with excellent, very sharp, highly lustrous, gemmy/translucent, pink colored quartz crystals measuring up to 8 mm filling the inside of the geode in which it formed. Virtually all of the crystals are in good condition, but the periphery is obviously contacted where the piece was broken apart. These are exciting, new and interesting pieces from this remote discovery in Argentina.

R.name: Azurite - Goethite - Limonite
R.description: An intergrown aggregate of very sharp, dark midnight blue Azurite crystals covers all sides of a small amount of dark brown Limonite/Goethite gossan matrix.

R.name: Fluorapatite - Muscovite - Calcite - Pyrite
R.description: Group of eight intergrown, tabular, light lavender color hexagonal Fluorapatite crystals on crystallized Muscovite matrix. The largest Fluorapatite crystal is 1.3 cm across. Tabular, micro white Calcite crystals are also present, along with scattered micro Pyrite crystals.

R.name: Malachite
R.description: This is a very rare cabinet sized example of what some refer to as 'latticework' malachite pseudomorphs after azurite, from Tsumeb. They only came out once in this quality, I am not sure when - and they are today as rare as hen's teeth, especially at size. This is one of the better examples I have seen of the material, with sharp crystals of excellent color, individually reaching 6 cm in length. The piece is a complete floater, complete all around. All major crystals are either terminated sharply and only in a few cases, are some minor crystals in the spray a little rough on the tips due to odd growth features, but still complete nonetheless. This is a superb specimen, a rare style, and a beautiful geometry. Ex Allen Dillwith Collection (he sold off his Tsumeb suite to focus on other suites).

R.name: Opal
R.description: Oregon Contra Luz Opal with botryoidal Jasper inclusions.

R.name: Prehnite - Epidote
R.description: Intergrown, light pistachio-green, translucent prehnite botryoids with nubby bladed surfaces nearly envelope lustrous, partially translucent olive-green epidote crystals on this sculptural and rich combination from 1990s to early 2000s finds in Mali. Fine prehnites from Mali, most often associated with deep green epidote crystals, are instantly recognizable to most collectors. See the 2011 Mineralogical Record article in Vol. 42, No. 3. A fine, representative small cabinet combination.

R.name: Pyrite
R.description: This pyrite cluster is from the world famous sharpest-of-sharp pyrite locality in Spain. These have been the gateway into collecting minerals for so many people over the decades since they started mining here for specimens, including Jack himself. The cubic crystals are well-formed and sharp. The satiny luster is quite good, and the faces have slight undulations that add definite character to the crystals. The largest pyrite crystal is 4.6 cm on edge and the piece is 600 grams in a small volume area, which is quite substantial. The quality of this small cabinet cluster are quite good, and it well-represents the family of great Spanish Pyrites. Jack obtained it from the great old Spanish dealer, Luis Leite (leitite). There are numerous references to Jack and his collection in print, but perhaps a good tour of the collection and its history will help give perspective on just how good, and important, this collection is:

R.name: Ruby (Corundum)
R.description: Gorgeous blood-red, partially gemmy ruby crystals on this remarkable, extremely rich small cabinet specimen from Jegdalek. The beautiful, lustrous stepped-growth crystals are set on all sides of the spare marble matrix. The striking, large, sharp, pseudo-octahedral crystal on the bottom is 2.6 cm, very large for the locale. Ex Chet Lemanski Collection. This is a classic, important and exceptionally rich small cabinet ruby specimen with fine color and a large crystal from the locale. It simply looks 'ruby' for color and luster, in a way that many specimens simply cannot do with impact. Cherry-red fluorescence. The fluorescence is simply breathtaking, as a bonus. NOTE: In LED lights, these look more pink-red. In room fluorescents, more classical red. In sunlight, sort of in between. Ruby like this has different color in different warmth of lighting.

R.name: Wulfenite
R.description: Impressive opposing tabular wulfenite crystals atop highlight this classic, older, rich and aesthetic small cabinet triangular plate covered with classic 'sandwich' style crystals from the renowned Erupcion Mine at Los Lamentos. The richly colored zoned prisms, to 2.0 cm, are translucent to opaque, adding character. It is starkly geometric, and this is a style known for its shape rather than its color - but unique to this day. The striking pair atop look like pages of an open book or wings of a bird or butterfly. Read about the famed locale in the 2003 Mineralogical Record article in Vol. 34, No. 6. Ex Bill Panczner Collection, of which Mexico was the primary specialty. Bill was the first Curator of Earth Science at the Arizona Sonora Desert Museum in 1974 and the author of the 1987 book Minerals of Mexico. It is the most thorough summary of the subject.

C.name: Aquamarine
C.description: Etched, gemmy, light blue aquamarine crystal.

C.name: Citrine (Quartz)
C.luster: Vitreous ‚Äì waxy to dull when massive

C.name: Diamond
C.description: Loose transparent diamond crystal weighing 1.08 ct.

C.name: Emerald (Beryl)
C.description: 1.2 x 0.5 x 0.3 cm. A superb, parallel pair of emerald crystals from Chivor, the rarest of the specimen mines for emeralds in this district. It produces little, but what it does give up is awesome for the superb luster and deep rich coloration. The crystals are totally gemmy, lustrous, and have a luscious, medium-green color with the slightest hint of blue (immediately recognizable as Chivor. It is simply a more intense color than emeralds of other mines). The tops of each edge are beveled like gems, and the two terminations are excellent. The weight for this pair is 3.36 ct. Emeralds of this quality are simply far and few between. It is a stunning thumbnail specimen of a gem species.

C.name: Peridot (Forsterite) - Ludwigite
C.description: Peridote with ludwigite needles, Sapat Gali (Soppat; Suppat; Sumpat), Manshera, Naran-Kagan Valley, Pakistan

C.name: Spinel
C.description: Deep red colour spinel crystals cluster, from Mogok, Sagaing District, Mandalay Division, Burma

C.name: Tanzanite (Zoisite)
C.description: Beside the deep blue saturated color, the strong glassy luster and the striation at the left side of the crystal parallel to the c-axis, I especially liked the sharp elongated and well defined shape of this very elegant Tanzanite.

C.name: Topaz
C.description: Glassy water clear gem quality transparent single terminated loose matrix-less topaz crystal measuring 3.8 x 2.7 x 2.4 cm in size. Complete all around and without damage. Ex Lloyd Tate collection.
